title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
Question. For a scoped snapshot: How did Bike Share Toronto usage differ between March 2023 and March 2024—by hour and weekday/weekend—and what changed in the member/casual mix?
Why these months? March alone already has ~500k+ trips across the two years—enough to reveal strong hourly patterns without boiling the ocean. I’ll scale the scope later.
Why I’m doing this. I’ve been seeing micromobility (bikes/scooters) all over Mississauga—often parked, sometimes deserted—and got curious about real usage and adoption. This project is my way to quantify it: start tight (two months), then expand into comparisons, models, and policy context (e-scooter restrictions).
Stack. Excel (cleaning/validation) · Tableau (dashboard) · Python/SQL (planned)

title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
Data & Scope

Source: Bike Share Toronto open data (Trips for Mar 2023 and Mar 2024)
Core fields: Trip Id, duration, start/end times, station IDs/names, bike ID, user type

Scope choice: one month per year to keep season similar yet volume high


Planned extension: add adjacent months to test before/after effects of downtown e-scooter restrictions (with citation).

title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
Excel Cleaning & Validation
I validated and cleaned both months with a reproducible Data_issues log rather than ad-hoc fixes.
Goals: fix types, remove duplicates, handle nulls, and create analysis-ready columns.

Steps I took

Type fixes: coerced timestamps to datetime; durations to numeric minutes

Null handling: filtered rows with missing station IDs/time; documented counts

De-duplication: removed duplicates by (start_time, end_time, bike_id)

Derived columns: Trip Duration (min), Start Date, Start Hour, Day of Week, Same Station?, Mappable

Data issues log: tracked anomalies (e.g., negative durations, unmapped station IDs)

title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
From Excel → Tableau (Data Model)
After cleaning, I imported both months into Tableau.

Union: Mar-2023 and Mar-2024 trip tables combined; added metadata (Year, Month).

Join: Station reference (ID → lat/long/name) for mapping; rows with missing reference flagged as Unmapped.

Fields used: duration (min), hour, weekday, member type, station IDs/names, Model (2024 only).

Visuals built: overview KPIs, Trips-by-Hour, weekday heatmap, and station map.

Next build: a comparison dashboard (side-by-side 2023 vs 2024).

title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
Dashboard Snapshot



Prefer the interactive version? View it on Tableau Public.

title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
Findings (So Far)

Peak hours (weekdays): clear commute peaks at 8–9 AM and 5–7 PM.

Weekends: usage is broader and more distributed (~11 AM–7 PM), with no sharp single peak.

Member mix: overall across the two months ≈ 21.5% members; the YoY change is small (≈≤ 2 percentage points from Mar-2023 → Mar-2024).

Ridership growth: total rides are higher in 2024, so general usage is up.

Routes: many round trips appear among top routes—likely loops/non-commute behavior (e.g., short errands, deliveries).


Limits: single month per year; weather not controlled; station reference partially outdated; promotions/policy context not yet incorporated.

title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
What’s Next

Comparison dashboard: KPIs and distributions (Mar-2023 vs Mar-2024) side-by-side.

2024 model usage: which bike model is most used, and by when/where?

Top routes (commute focus): analyze flows excluding round trips to better isolate commuting.

Policy check: add months around the e-scooter restriction date to test for a measurable before/after effect.

Python/SQL pipeline: reproducible cleaning and station-hour aggregations.

Predictive baseline: simple hourly demand model for top stations (limitations documented).

title: CityBike: Toronto Bike Share Snapshot (Mar 2023 vs Mar 2024)
text:
Repro Notes

Assumptions: local timezone; station names normalized by ID when possible.

Files referenced: data_issues.xlsx (this project), screenshots under /images/.

Notes on mapping: trips with unknown/new station IDs are kept but flagged Unmapped to avoid dropping real rides.

title: Zain Ghias
text:
Hi, I’m Zain,
a third-year student at the University of Toronto Mississauga, majoring in Applied Statistics with minors in Computer Science and Math.
I’m currently working as a Software Developer Intern at a startup, but I’m shifting my focus toward Data Analytics, Data Science, and exploring areas like AI and Machine Learning. I’m planning to take more ML and stats courses next year, and I’m open to getting involved in research if it’s in something exciting or meaningful.
I like volleyball, table tennis, and basketball, and I try to balance screen time with touching grass and going on long walks, partly for my sanity.
Thanks for stopping by. Excited to see where this journey goes.
Get in touch: zain.ghias@mail.utoronto.ca
